First of all, the observation that stuck out most to me is that mud is connected to the Tullys and the Riverlands, explicitly and repeatedly. And it is a sort of reddish mud: red mud and blue water are the Tully colours.

Catelyn raised her eyes, to where the faint red line of the comet traced a path across the deep blue sky like a long scratch across the face of god. “The Greatjon told Robb that the old gods have unfurled a red flag of vengeance for Ned. Edmure thinks it’s an omen of victory for Riverrun—he sees a fish with a long tail, in the Tully colors, red against blue.” She sighed. “I wish I had their faith. Crimson is a Lannister color.”

“That thing’s not crimson,” Ser Brynden said. “Nor Tully red, the mud red of the river. That’s blood up there, child, smeared across the sky.”(ACOK, Catelyn I)

Repeatedly the Tullys enter the stage all muddied: first of all Edmure Tully (ACOK, Catelyn VI, ASOS, Catelyn I, and AFFC, Jaime VI), but also the Blackfish (ACOK, Catelyn I). Catelyn herself seems positively fond of mud. She fondly remembers baking ‘mud pies’ with Lysa and Petyr when they were children, and during her travels in AGOT she also gets muddy quite often – and seems to like it:

“It is only water, Ser Rodrik,” Catelyn replied. Her hair hung wet and heavy, a loose strand stuck to her forehead, and she could imagine how ragged and wild she must look, but for once she did not care. The southern rain was soft and warm. Catelyn liked the feel of it on her face, gentle as a mother’s kisses. It took her back to her childhood, to long grey days at Riverrun. She remembered the godswood, drooping branches heavy with moisture, and the sound of her brother’s laughter as he chased her through piles of damp leaves. She remembered making mud pies with Lysa, the weight of them, the mud slick and brown between her fingers. They had served them to Littlefinger, giggling, and he’d eaten so much mud he was sick for a week. How young they all had been. (AGOT, Catelyn V)

The mud of the river is also the graveyard of the Tullys, as we learn at the ‘burial’ of Hoster Tully.

And then it was gone … drifting downriver still, perhaps, or broken up and sinking. The weight of his armor would carry Lord Hoster down to rest in the soft mud of the riverbed, in the watery halls where the Tullys held eternal court, with schools of fish their last attendants. (ASOS, Catelyn IV)

Catelyn herself is resurrected from the mud as Lady Stoneheart when Nymeria drags her out of the river (ASOS, Arya XII).

There is even a connection of mud and the Riverlands in F&B: Harren the Black complains about…

“these traitors of the Trident, these lords of yellow mud.” (F&B, Aegon’s conquest).

This should be enough to establish that mud has a strong Tully connection and therefore it is interesting to look at how mud is depicted in the arcs of Catelyn’s children.

2) Sansa and Bran

In Sansa’s PoV mud occurs exactly only once as it touches her, and it is no actual mud but just the feeling of not being able to walk:

She forced herself to take King Joffrey’s hand. The climb was something out of a nightmare; every step was a struggle, as if she were pulling her feet out of ankle-deep mud, and there were more steps than she would have believed, a thousand thousand steps, and horror waiting on the ramparts. (AGOT, Sansa VI)

We have to count out the Mud Gate in King’s Landing. Now, of course Sansa stays mostly indoors, and in the Vale she is confronted with snow, not mud, but it is at least worth noting, I think, that mud does not occur often in her POV, not in connection to her anyway.

Bran’s PoV doesn’t exactly overflow with mud connections either. One very interesting occurrence is when he plays with the Frey wards in ACOK. The Freys are the traitors and I would alert you to the fact that mud is connected to blood in this case.

… until Little Walder had smacked Rickon with the stick, square across his belly. Before Bran could blink, the black wolf was flying over the plank, there was blood in the water, the Walders were shrieking red murder, Rickon sat in the mud laughing, and Hodor came lumbering in shouting “Hodor! Hodor! Hodor!” (ACOK, Bran I)

So, neither Bran nor Sansa have a very strong Tully/water magic connection. That is completely different for

3) Arya

There is no lack of mud, not at all. Interestingly it is in Sansa’s Pov that we see her connection to mud for the first time:

She found Arya on the banks of the Trident, trying to hold Nymeria still while she brushed dried mud from her fur. (AGOT, Sansa I)

The direwolves give hints about the personas of their owners, and it is extremely interesting that we see Nymeria covered in mud through Sansa’s eyes.

And I think it is interesting that we see her happily playing in the mud, just like Catelyn did:

None of which stopped Arya, of course. One day she came back grinning her horsey grin, her hair all tangled and her clothes covered in mud, clutching a raggedy bunch of purple and green flowers for Father. Sansa kept hoping he would tell Arya to behave herself and act like the highborn lady she was supposed to be, but he never did, he only hugged her and thanked her for the flowers. That just made her worse.

Then it turned out the purple flowers were called poison kisses, and Arya got a rash on her arms. Sansa would have thought that might have taught her a lesson, but Arya laughed about it, and the next day she rubbed mud all over her arms like some ignorant bog woman just because her friend Mycah told her it would stop the itching. (AGOT, Sansa I)

Here we see connection of mud and healing qualities – which might be a nod to the earth magic.

I do think that Arya’s strong connection to mud has multiple purposes: It shows, that Arya, who looks like Ned, also has a very strong connection to her mother, and actually is far more similar to her in temper than she is to Ned. Others have made this observation before me: Arya looks like Ned, but is like Catelyn in temper, while Sansa looks like Catelyn, but has several traits of Ned. I do think that this further points towards the fact that Arya will meet Lady Stoneheart at one time in the book and will be present at the Red Wedding 2.0. (as she was in the show).

Mud repeatedly occurs to ‘ground’ Arya when she is on the run. It gives a hint about the people she can trust. When Yoren talks with Ned, and Arya sees him, the man from the Watch who will take her away from King’s Landing he wears mud-cacked boots (AGOT, Eddard VII).

Later when Arya travels with Yoren, it is Hot Pie, part of her ‘new’ family who is called ‘mud pie’:

Lommy and Tarber stripped naked and went wading, and Lommy scooped up handfuls of slimy mud and threw them at Hot Pie, shouting, “Mud Pie! Mud Pie!” (ACOK, Arya IV).

This is a clear connection to Catelyn baking mud pies with her sister.

In addition, Arya feels positively good with water and mud:

Despondent, she climbed off her horse and knelt by the lake. The water lapped softly around her legs. A few lantern bugs were coming out, their little lights blinking on and off. The green water was warm as tears, but there was no salt in it. It tasted of summer and mud and growing things. Arya plunged her face down into it to wash off the dust and dirt and sweat of the day. When she leaned back the trickles ran down the back of her neck and under her collar. They felt good. (ACOK, Arya IV)

And later in the same chapter, crawling in the mud saves her life:

Arya rolled headfirst into the tunnel and dropped five feet. She got dirt in her mouth but she didn’t care, the taste was fine, the taste was mud and water and worms and life. Under the earth the air was cool and dark. Above was nothing but blood and roaring red and choking smoke and the screams of dying horses. She moved her belt around so Needle would not be in her way, and began to crawl. A dozen feet down the tunnel she heard the sound, like the roar of some monstrous beast, and a cloud of hot smoke and black dust came billowing up behind her, smelling of hell. Arya held her breath and kissed the mud on the floor of the tunnel and cried. For whom, she could not say.  (ACOK, Arya IV)

Later when she has to walk barefoot she does not mind:

The mud was nice between her toes, and she liked to feel the earth underfoot when she walked. (ACOK, Arya V)

Arya is - at least it looks like that - directly identified with mud, although the woman might be talking about Lem here:

The painted sign above the door showed a picture of some old king on his knees. Inside was the common room, where a very tall ugly woman with a knobby chin stood with her hands on her hips, glaring. “Don’t just stand there, boy,” she snapped. “Or are you a girl? Either one, you’re blocking my door. Get in or get out. Lem, what did I tell you about my floor? You’re all mud.” (ASOS, Arya II)

I think it is interesting that Jaqen as one of the men who seemingly helps Arya has no connection to mud. The magic of the faceless men seems to draw Arya away from her family. It is no earth/water magic.

There is only one time, where Arya has a distinctively bad feeling about mud. It is a very ominous dream of Arya, which is a foreshadowing of the Red Wedding and her inability to help her family. It is also a back reference to Sansa and her inability to help her father (who was already beheaded by the time she walked through ‘ankle-deep mud’, forced by Joffrey to look at her father’s head).

She dreamt of home; not Riverrun, but Winterfell. It was not a good dream, though. She was alone outside the castle, up to her knees in mud. She could see the grey walls ahead of her, but when she tried to reach the gates every step seemed harder than the one before, and the castle faded before her, until it looked more like smoke than granite. (ASOS, Arya III)

Just like Sansa couldn’t help her father, Arya can’t help her mother and Robb.

This all cumulates in the almost reunion at the Red Wedding where mud occurs very frequently in Arya’s PoV.

“Come with me.” Sandor Clegane reached down a hand. “We have to get away from here, and now.” Stranger tossed his head impatiently, his nostrils flaring at the scent of blood. The song was done. There was only one solitary drum, its slow monotonous beats echoing across the river like the pounding of some monstrous heart. The black sky wept, the river grumbled, men cursed and died. Arya had mud in her teeth and her face was wet. Rain. It’s only rain. That’s all it is. “We’re here,” she shouted. Her voice sounded thin and scared, a little girl’s voice. “Robb’s just in the castle, and my mother. The gate’s even open.” There were no more Freys riding out. I came so far. “We have to go get my mother.” (ASOS, Arya IX)

The most heartbreaking connection of mud to Arya’s family and in particular her mother is still to come though: Nymeria drags Catelyn’s corpse from the mud of the river (remember the burial place of the Tullys) but she cannot help Catelyn, who is dead.

… and then she could smell her. The scent was faint beneath the other smells, beneath moss and mud and water, and the stench of rotting reeds and rotting men. She padded slowly through the soft ground to the river’s edge, lapped up a drink, the lifted her head to sniff. The sky was grey and thick with cloud, the river green and full of floating things. Dead men clogged the shallows, some still moving as the water pushed them, others washed up on the banks. ….

She splashed noisily through the shallows and threw herself into the deeper water, her legs churning. The current was strong but she was stronger. She swam, following her nose. The river smells were rich and wet, but those were not the smells that pulled her. She paddled after the sharp red whisper of cold blood, the sweet cloying stench of death. She chased them as she had often chased a red deer through the trees, and in the end she ran them down, and her jaw closed around a pale white arm. She shook it to make it move, but there was only death and blood in her mouth. By now she was tiring, and it was all she could do to pull the body back to shore. As she dragged it up the muddy bank, one of her little brothers came prowling, his tongue lolling from his mouth. She had to snarl to drive him off, or else he would have fed. Only then did she stop to shake the water from her fur. The white thing lay facedown in the mud, her dead flesh wrinkled and pale, cold blood trickling from her throat. Rise, she thought. Rise and eat and run with us. (ASOS, Arya XII)

I do think that the colour red probably is put here to make a connection to the red of the Tully mud, and of course the blood that was spilt when Catelyn was killed.

It is interesting, that as soon as Arya is in Braavos, the occurrence of mud decreases, because she disconnects with her family. It is also a strong hint, that the Faceless men will not be Arya’s family, that she’ll ultimately reject being part of them (like she did on the show). It is only in Arya’s dreams, that mud occurs:

It was the other dream she hated, the one where she had two feet instead of four. In that one she was always looking for her mother, stumbling through a wasted land of mud and blood and fire. It was always raining in that dream, and she could hear her mother screaming, but a monster with a dog’s head would not let her go save her. In that dream she was always weeping, like a frightened little girl. Cats never weep, she told herself, no more than wolves do. It’s just a stupid dream. (AFFC, Cat of the Canals)

Clearly, this dream is induced by Arya’s trauma.

So, mud, the combination of earth and water clearly occurs to ‘ground’ Arya, to give her a connection to her mother’s family, which will come into play again, once she returns to Westeros. But the Tully connection, earth/water magic connection is not the only thing that stands out about mud.

4) Mud and Blood

Another interesting find in connection with mud is that there are multiple times that mud and blood are connected. In a way, this occurs naturally, the gritty realism of the fighting in GRRM’s world is pictured by ‘dirty’ fights and therefore mud often occurs in fights, e.g at the tourney in King’s Landing (AGOT, Eddard VII), or Robert’s death (AGOT, Eddard XIII). Also, this fight of Brienne and Jaime might be put here:

Brienne lurched to her feet. She was all mud and blood below the waist, her clothing askew, her face red. She looks as if they caught us fucking instead of fighting. (ASOS, Jaime III)

As well as this fight from Asha’s PoV

When he fell, Hagen’s daughter stumbled to her knees, snatched up his sword, stabbed the second man, then rose again, smeared with blood and mud, her long red hair unbound, and plunged into the fight. (ADWD, The Wayward bride)

So, these are just two examples where the mud adds to the ‘dirtyness’ of fighting, there are many more.

5) Mud and slipping/falling

A very special case of mud and fighting is when a fight ends with someone lying in the mud. Over the course of ASOIAF several people come to lay in the mud, wounded, hurt or near to death, and I think this might be way to alert us to a connection of mud and death.

The very first time is in the prologue – which is also a foreshadowing of Jon’s death as @lady-in-a-song has shown:

The great sentinel was right there at the top of the ridge, where Will had known it would be, its lowest branches a bare foot off the ground. Will slid in underneath, flat on his belly in the snow and the mud, and looked down on the empty clearing below. (AGOT, Prologue)

When Ned and Jaime fight, Ned falls from his horse and lies in the mud:

Ned’s horse slipped under him and came crashing down in the mud. There was a moment of blinding pain and the taste of blood in his mouth. (AGOT, Eddard IX)

When he opened his eyes again, Lord Eddard Stark was alone with his dead. His horse moved closer, caught the rank scent of blood, and galloped away. Ned began to drag himself through the mud, gritting his teeth at the agony in his leg. It seemed to take years. (AGOT, Eddard IX)

Tyrion also has a muddy experience in his first battle:

Tyrion lurched to his feet, driving his head into the horse’s belly. The animal gave a hideous scream and reared. It tried to twist away from the agony, a shower of blood and viscera poured down over Tyrion’s face, and the horse fell like an avalanche. The next he knew, his visor was packed with mud and something was crushing his foot. He wriggled free, his throat so tight he could scarce talk. “… yield …” he managed to croak faintly. (AGOT, Tyrion VIII))

Several people land on their arses in the mud, which is not necessarily connected to dying. Arya does when she travels with the hound (ASOS, Arya XI), Podrick Payne falls in the mud, when Brienne catches him spying on her (AFFC, Brienne II) and Jaime kisses the muddy ground in his training exercise with Ser Ilyn (AFFC, Jaime V).

Yet, coming to fall in the mud, might be considered a bad omen, or at least a sign of sudden change. I think that mud and blood connected are not only there to convey a ‘dirty’ fight, but also to foreshadow bad things to come. It is no happenstance that Ned falls into the mud when he is confronted by Jaime Lannister in the streets of King’s Landing.

It is interesting that we see Ser Criston Cole, the commander of the King’s Guard, and in part a Jaime stand-in, actually killing a man in the mud:

Cole’s favorite weapon was the Morningstar, and the blows he rained done on Ser Laenor’s champion cracked his helm and left him senseless in the mud. Borne bloody from the field, Ser Joffrey died without recovering consciousness six days later. (F&B, Heirs of the dragon)

The scene with the most ominous foreshadowing is Jon: He is thrown into the mud, when he is attacked by Orell’s eagle. Jon’s fall and death and loss of an eye (on this compare @rose-of-red-lake) are foreshadowed several times, and Ned’s fall into the mud might be another hint to Jon’s falling, which we see here:

The next he knew, he was on his face with the taste of mud and blood in his mouth and Ygritte kneeling over him protectively, a bone dagger in her hand. He could still hear wings, though the eagle was not in sight. Half his world was black. “My eye,” he said in sudden panic, raising a hand to his face. …. “There’s your hellcrow!” Rattleshirt pointed at Jon. “Bleeding in the mud like a faithless dog!” The eagle came flapping down to land atop the broken giant’s skull that served him for his helm. “I’m here for him.” (ASOS, Jon II)

I would alert you to the fact that Duncan the Tall in the Hedge Knight also has a scene with mud and blood – and he is temporarily blinded by blood in his eye.

When his eyes opened he was on the ground again, sprawled on his back. The mud had all been knocked from his helm, but now one eye was closed by blood. Above was nothing but dark grey sky. (The Hedge Knight)

A variant of this mud and blood connection is, when Khal Drogo is dying. He does not lie in the mud, but the mud plasters on his wound get mixed with blood.

When they were alone, Ser Jorah drew his dagger. Deftly, with a delicacy surprising in such a big man, he began to scrape away the black leaves and dried blue mud from Drogo’s chest. The plaster had caked hard as the mud walls of the Lamb Men, and like those walls it cracked easily. Ser Jorah broke the dry mud with his knife, pried the chunks from the flesh, peeled off the leaves one by one. A foul, sweet smell rose from the wound, so thick it almost choked her. The leaves were crusted with blood and pus, Drogo’s breast black and glistening with corruption. (AGOT, Daenerys VIII)

I think it is extremely interesting that the mud, that was used to cover his wounds is of blue colour, a Tully colour maybe?

5) Mud and death

But this is not all there is to ‘mud’. We have seen sliding in the ‘mud’ is a real danger for anyone fighting, but mud can be deadly in other ways as well:

During their travels Brienne and Podrick chance upon dangerous mud:

“Stay off the mud, child,” counseled Septon Meribald. “The mud is not fond of strangers. If you walk in the wrong place, it will open up and swallow you.”

“It’s only mud,” insisted Podrick.

“Until it fills your mouth and starts creeping up your nose. Then it’s death.” He smiled to take the chill off his words. “Wipe off that mud and have a slice of orange, lad.” (AFFC, Brienne V)

And later:

“If you would sleep beneath a roof tonight, you must climb off your horses and cross the mud with me. The path of faith, we call it. Only the faithful may cross safely. The wicked are swallowed by the quicksands, or drowned when the tide comes rushing in. None of you are wicked, I hope? Even so, I would be careful where I set my feet. Walk only where I walk, and you shall reach the other side.” (AFFC, Brienne VI)

There is even mud in connection with quicksands in one of Sansa’s chapters, the only time apart from her walking towards the rampart as if through ankle-deep mud, where mud has an appearance in her chapters and is not connected to Arya:

Huge flowers bloomed in the mud and floated on pools of stagnant water, but if you were stupid enough to leave the causeway to pluck them, there were quicksands waiting to suck you down, and snakes watching from the trees, and lizard-lions floating half-submerged in the water, like black logs with eyes and teeth. (AGOT, Sansa I)

Ser Davos has a near death experience after the Battle of the Blackwater and the mud proves dangerous in this case as well.

Panic took hold of him. His hands flailed against the bottom of the river and sent up a cloud of mud that blinded him. His chest was growing tighter by the instant. He clawed at the water, kicking, pushing himself, turning, his lungs screaming for air, kicking, kicking, lost now in the river murk, kicking, kicking, kicking until he could kick no longer. When he opened his mouth to scream, the water came rushing in, tasting of salt, and Davos Seaworth knew that he was drowning. (ASOS Davos I)

The incident in F&B, where an archmaester dies of slipping in the mud, might be a hint as well:

He proved more robust than his predecessor, serving the realm until 12 AC, when he slipped in the mud, broke his hip, and died soon thereafter…. (F&B, Three heads had the dragon)

I mean this might be coincidence, but GRRM could have simply said: He took a fall?

So, what is it with dangerous mud? Is this a hint that Arya will become very deadly indeed?

There is yet another thing, but I’m not entirely sure what to make of it:

6) Mud and (horse)shit

Another interesting tidbit is this scene with Theon on Pyke

Theon knelt. He had a purpose here, and might need Aeron’s help to achieve it. A crown was worth a little mud and horseshit on his breeches, he supposed. (ACOK, Theon I)

 - a very strange wording and connection of mud and shit, but one that happens again, with Jon of all people:

Go on, I’ll see to your horse. If it’s warm and dry inside, don’t tell me, I wasn’t asked in.“ He flicked a glob of wet mud out from under a horseshoe. "Does this mud look like shit to you? Could it be that this whole hill is made of Craster’s shit?” (ACOK, Jon III).

I would like to link this to the following from Catelyn’s chapters:

“The distance between a lord and a grace is a small one, my lady,” Catelyn said. “Lord Renly wears a crown, as does my son. If you wish, we may stand here in the mud and debate what honors and titles are rightly due to each, but it strikes me that we have more pressing matters to consider.” (ACOK, Catelyn II)

Is this a hint to the debate to come when the lords will discuss Jon’s claim to the crown?

So mud might be even involved with the making of a king? This is admittedly very tinfoily….

7) Mud as a part of nature

Another very prominent occurrence of mud is the connection of mud with Prince Quentyn, the ‘wrong suitor’, the frog prince who was not saved by princess Dany but failed in his bride quest. This is what Barristan has to say about Quentyn being mud :

She wants fire, and Dorne sent her mud.

You could make a poultice out of mud to cool a fever. You could plant seeds in mud and grow a crop to feed your children. Mud would nourish you, where fire would only consume you, but fools and children and young girls would choose fire every time. (ADWD, the discarded knight)

Here mud has very positive connotations, something that connects mud to healing and fertility.

So, mud is much more dangerous than people allow for, but is also good. It’s not just water and earth, there is more to it and maybe even the connection of mud and death might have a positive aspect:

Firewights of Rh’llor and the icewights of the Others are unnatural, and if it is indeed Arya’s fate to come to a deeper understanding of mercy, justice and revenge, then the final death of Lady Stoneheart – which she probably will witness – brings the natural order back.

I suggest that mud might point not only to Tullys, to danger and to death, but that it might also point towards a fall and a sudden change.

Arya is the ‘wild card’. Where her allegiance lies, will probably be crucial, and the despised mud might become dangerous up to a point where the mud can suffocate and kill someone.

7) Mud and danger

Finally, I would alert you to some ominous foreshadowing of mud and water besides the connection to Khal Drogo’s death I have discussed already.

Mud features heavily in the tragic story of Da€nerys, Drogo and Mirri Maaz Duur.

“I meant no wrong, fierce riders.” The woman spoke Dothraki well. The robes she wore had once been the lightest and finest of woolens, rich with embroidery, but now they were mud-caked and bloody and ripped. She clutched the torn cloth of her bodice to her heavy breasts. “I have some small skill in the healing arts.” (AGOT, Daenerys VII)

Mirri is a healer, and it is interesting that her and her magic (we only see her practicing blood magic, but it stands to reason that her normal way of magic would be ‘earth-bound’).

Khal Drogo waved him away. “I need no man’s help,” he said, in a voice proud and hard. He stood, unaided, towering over them all. A fresh wave of blood ran down his breast, from where Ogo’s arakh had cut off his nipple. Dany moved quickly to his side. “I am no man,” she whispered, “so you may lean on me.” Drogo put a huge hand on her shoulder. She took some of his weight as they walked toward the great mud temple. The three bloodriders followed. Dany commanded Ser Jorah and the warriors of her khas to guard the entrance and make certain no one set the building afire while they were still inside. (AGOT, Daenerys VII)

I would alert you to the fact, that Khal Drogo burns the mud temple of the Lamb people. So, MMD connected to mud via her religion – which is a religion that seems to be heavily influenced by earth and nature worship  – is an antagonist of Da€nerys.

Considering that Da€nerys lives in a hot climate, the rare occurrence of mud may alert us to important crossroads of her arc.

The procession waited on the grassy shore as Dany stripped and let her soiled clothing fall to the ground. Naked, she stepped gingerly into the water. Irri said the lake had no bottom, but Dany felt soft mud squishing between her toes as she pushed through the tall reeds. The moon floated on the still black waters, shattering and re-forming as her ripples washed over it. Goose pimples rose on her pale skin as the coldness crept up her thighs and kissed her lower lips. The stallion’s blood had dried on her hands and around her mouth. Dany cupped her fingers and lifted the sacred waters over her head, cleansing herself and the child inside her while the khal and the others looked on. She heard the old women of the dosh khaleen muttering to each other as they watched, and wondered what they were saying. (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

This happens after Da€nerys ate the horse heart and awaits the dosh khaleen’s prophecy on the future of her child, the “stallion who mounts the world”. This is when Viserys dies and she sets herself on the path towards winning the Iron Throne for herself.

In her last chapter in ADWD (Da€nerys X) there is a recollection of the time she was pregnant with Rhaego:

It was quiet on her sea. When the wind blew the grass would sigh as the stalks brushed against each other, whispering in a tongue that only gods could understand. Now and again the little stream would gurgle where it flowed around a stone. Mud squished between her toes. Insects buzzed around her, lazy dragonflies and glistening green wasps and stinging midges almost too small to see. She swatted at them absently when they landed on her arms.

Her last chapter in ADWD is also important, because she really embraces her house words ‘fire and blood’, the last step in her transition from a frightened child to a ruthless conqueror. This is also the chapter, where we see her possibly having a miscarriage:

Her belly was empty, her feet sore and blistered, and it seemed to her that the cramping had grown worse. Her guts were full of writhing snakes biting at her bowels. She scooped up a handful of mud and water in trembling hands. By midday the water would be tepid, but in the chill of dawn it was almost cool and helped her keep her eyes open. As she splashed her face, she saw fresh blood on her thighs. The ragged hem of her undertunic was stained with it. The sight of so much red frightened her. Moon blood, it’s only my moon blood, but she did not remember ever having such a heavy flow. Could it be the water? If it was the water, she was doomed. She had to drink or die of thirst. (ADWD Daenerys X)

Very tentatively I would suggest that ‘mud’ and/ or water does not bode well for Da€nerys. If it was the water, she was doomed. Who has the strongest connection to the Riverlands? Who is a waterdancer? Arya, the wild card, will be threat to Da€nerys I’m sure of it.

To sum up:

Mud as a combination of earth and water has a connection to the CotF and might be usable to balance the dangerous opposites of fire and ice.

Mud is a tell-tale Tully word. The red mud of the river is a sign for Tully, and it shows clearly that appearances put aside, Arya is the child that is most closely connected to the Tully and the Riverlands and will probably witness the Red Wedding 2.0. and the final death of the unnaturally resurrected Lady Stoneheart. Arya possibly will choose mud over fire.

Mud and blood are used repeatedly – and many more times when I put down here as examples – to picture the dirtiness of fighting. Mud also has healing qualities, but can be dangerous as well (as every magic). We see this rarely, but nevertheless in every book and in several PoVs.

There is a connection between mud and death. Slipping in the mud can mean a sudden change to a fight and deadly danger. I would alert you to the fact that the healing qualities of mud only go awry when the healing women of the Dothraki fail to heal Khal Drogo.

Looking at Da€nerys’ arc I would say that mud does not bode well for her. Mud as a reminder of a more grounded life occurs at several crossroads in her arc, shortly before Viserys’ death, with MMD, with the rejection of Quentyn’s offer of marriage and the decision for her house words in her last chapter in ADWD. I think it points towards the fact that the very personification of ‘mud’, Arya Stark will cause a turn in Da€nerys’ story. I do think it is a further hint that Arya will be the death of Da€nerys.
trail.content:
In ASOIAF we have two very obvious sources of magic: The Ice of the WW north of the Wall and the fire that is present in the dragons and Rh’llors magic. Both magics seem to be very strong – both the WW and the servants of Rh’llor can resurrect the dead – producing ice wights or fire wights, respectively.

It has puzzled me for some time, that as regards to the traditional four elements “earth, fire, air and water”, the two opposites “ice and fire” do not exactly match. Fire obviously melts ice, but then ice becomes water that will extinguish the fire in turn. So, why ice and not water as an opposite to fire?

I put this under the cut because it became huge…

The show gave us a big hint as to the origins of the White Walkers. We saw the Children of the Forest make the first White Walker aka the Night King, and it seems pretty clear, that the WW – at least in the show – are an experiment of the CotF that has gone awry. The CotF woke ice magic and it developed an agenda of its own. It can be argued that the books might go in the same direction. There are hints that the Others are a problem the CotF created and that they finally allied with the First men to get rid of the threat – and did not succeed entirely.

So, ice magic might be a variant of earth and water (or nature) magic, that has spiralled out of control. This instigated me to look at what we have in regard to earth magic and water magic.

I do think that from the description of the CotF in AWOIAF it is pretty clear, that the CotF do have an element of nature and earth magic.

The gods the children worshipped were the nameless ones that would one day become the gods of the First Men—the innumerable gods of the streams and forests and stones. (AWOIAF, The Dawn Age)

And also in Bran’s PoV we have some hints to earth magic, most blatantly in the oath of Jojen and Meera Reed, who as ‘frog-eaters’ from the Neck have very close connection to nature. In addition, their small stature probably makes them stand-ins for the CotF if not even descendants.

“I swear it by earth and water,” said the boy in green.

“I swear it by bronze and iron,” his sister said.

“We swear it by ice and fire,” they finished together.

(ACOK, Bran III)

This oath is surely a fogged memory about the first oath between CotF and the First men. Earth and Water is the magic of the CotF, bronze and iron are weapons (iron in legends being specifically a weapon of men, not to be used by the faerie, elves or however you want to call them) and ice and fire is the common enemy.

“No,” said Meera, “but he could breathe mud and run on leaves, and change earth to water and water to earth with no more than a whispered word. He could talk to trees and weave words and make castles appear and disappear.” (ASOS, Bran II)

Here Meera talks about her father, or rather about the legendary version of him. I would alert you to the fact, that earth and water are interchangeable and that there is an obvious stage of transmission as mud.

Also Bran’s experience while warging summer have a very earthy and magical vibe to them:

The evening’s rain had woken a hundred sleeping smells and made them ripe and strong again. Grass and thorns, blackberries broken on the ground, mud, worms, rotting leaves, a rat creeping through the bush. He caught the shaggy black scent of his brother’s coat and the sharp coppery tang of blood from the squirrel he’d killed. Other squirrels moved through the branches above, smelling of wet fur and fear, their little claws scratching at the bark. The noise had sounded something like that. (ACOK, Bran VI)

There is also the very real magical moment Jon experiences north of the wall, when he is at a place where the CotF might have influence.

The pale pink light of dawn sparkled on branch and leaf and stone. Every blade of grass was carved from emerald, every drip of water turned to diamond. Flowers and mushrooms alike wore coats of glass. Even the mud puddles had a bright brown sheen. Through the shimmering greenery, the black tents of his brothers were encased in a fine glaze of ice.

So there is magic beyond the Wall after all. He found himself thinking of his sisters, perhaps because he’d dreamed of them last night. Sansa would call this an enchantment, and tears would fill her eyes at the wonder of it, but Arya would run out laughing and shouting, wanting to touch it all. (ACOK, Jon III)

Now, this made me wonder again, how earth and water come into play for the arcs of our characters in ASOIAF and that in turn led me to look at the Tullys and the word “mud” – the connection of earth and water and I think I found some connections that might be worth pondering.

@lostlittlesatellites told me to be cautious about that, because, you know, mud happens if it rains, and it is no wonder that we see mud a lot in some of the PoVs, but still there are some interesting observations to be made. So, my following deliberations are not based on every mention of the word ‘mud’, because I would argue that sometimes ‘mud’ is just ‘mud’ and not a hint to the earth and water magic.

1) Tully mud

First of all, the observation that stuck out most to me is that mud is connected to the Tullys and the Riverlands, explicitly and repeatedly. And it is a sort of reddish mud: red mud and blue water are the Tully colours.

Catelyn raised her eyes, to where the faint red line of the comet traced a path across the deep blue sky like a long scratch across the face of god. “The Greatjon told Robb that the old gods have unfurled a red flag of vengeance for Ned. Edmure thinks it’s an omen of victory for Riverrun—he sees a fish with a long tail, in the Tully colors, red against blue.” She sighed. “I wish I had their faith. Crimson is a Lannister color.”

“That thing’s not crimson,” Ser Brynden said. “Nor Tully red, the mud red of the river. That’s blood up there, child, smeared across the sky.”(ACOK, Catelyn I)

Repeatedly the Tullys enter the stage all muddied: first of all Edmure Tully (ACOK, Catelyn VI, ASOS, Catelyn I, and AFFC, Jaime VI), but also the Blackfish (ACOK, Catelyn I). Catelyn herself seems positively fond of mud. She fondly remembers baking ‘mud pies’ with Lysa and Petyr when they were children, and during her travels in AGOT she also gets muddy quite often – and seems to like it:

“It is only water, Ser Rodrik,” Catelyn replied. Her hair hung wet and heavy, a loose strand stuck to her forehead, and she could imagine how ragged and wild she must look, but for once she did not care. The southern rain was soft and warm. Catelyn liked the feel of it on her face, gentle as a mother’s kisses. It took her back to her childhood, to long grey days at Riverrun. She remembered the godswood, drooping branches heavy with moisture, and the sound of her brother’s laughter as he chased her through piles of damp leaves. She remembered making mud pies with Lysa, the weight of them, the mud slick and brown between her fingers. They had served them to Littlefinger, giggling, and he’d eaten so much mud he was sick for a week. How young they all had been. (AGOT, Catelyn V)

The mud of the river is also the graveyard of the Tullys, as we learn at the ‘burial’ of Hoster Tully.

And then it was gone … drifting downriver still, perhaps, or broken up and sinking. The weight of his armor would carry Lord Hoster down to rest in the soft mud of the riverbed, in the watery halls where the Tullys held eternal court, with schools of fish their last attendants. (ASOS, Catelyn IV)

Catelyn herself is resurrected from the mud as Lady Stoneheart when Nymeria drags her out of the river (ASOS, Arya XII).

There is even a connection of mud and the Riverlands in F&B: Harren the Black complains about…

“these traitors of the Trident, these lords of yellow mud.” (F&B, Aegon’s conquest).

This should be enough to establish that mud has a strong Tully connection and therefore it is interesting to look at how mud is depicted in the arcs of Catelyn’s children.

2) Sansa and Bran

In Sansa’s PoV mud occurs exactly only once as it touches her, and it is no actual mud but just the feeling of not being able to walk:

She forced herself to take King Joffrey’s hand. The climb was something out of a nightmare; every step was a struggle, as if she were pulling her feet out of ankle-deep mud, and there were more steps than she would have believed, a thousand thousand steps, and horror waiting on the ramparts. (AGOT, Sansa VI)

We have to count out the Mud Gate in King’s Landing. Now, of course Sansa stays mostly indoors, and in the Vale she is confronted with snow, not mud, but it is at least worth noting, I think, that mud does not occur often in her POV, not in connection to her anyway.

Bran’s PoV doesn’t exactly overflow with mud connections either. One very interesting occurrence is when he plays with the Frey wards in ACOK. The Freys are the traitors and I would alert you to the fact that mud is connected to blood in this case.

… until Little Walder had smacked Rickon with the stick, square across his belly. Before Bran could blink, the black wolf was flying over the plank, there was blood in the water, the Walders were shrieking red murder, Rickon sat in the mud laughing, and Hodor came lumbering in shouting “Hodor! Hodor! Hodor!” (ACOK, Bran I)

So, neither Bran nor Sansa have a very strong Tully/water magic connection. That is completely different for

3) Arya

There is no lack of mud, not at all. Interestingly it is in Sansa’s Pov that we see her connection to mud for the first time:

She found Arya on the banks of the Trident, trying to hold Nymeria still while she brushed dried mud from her fur. (AGOT, Sansa I)

The direwolves give hints about the personas of their owners, and it is extremely interesting that we see Nymeria covered in mud through Sansa’s eyes.

And I think it is interesting that we see her happily playing in the mud, just like Catelyn did:

None of which stopped Arya, of course. One day she came back grinning her horsey grin, her hair all tangled and her clothes covered in mud, clutching a raggedy bunch of purple and green flowers for Father. Sansa kept hoping he would tell Arya to behave herself and act like the highborn lady she was supposed to be, but he never did, he only hugged her and thanked her for the flowers. That just made her worse.

Then it turned out the purple flowers were called poison kisses, and Arya got a rash on her arms. Sansa would have thought that might have taught her a lesson, but Arya laughed about it, and the next day she rubbed mud all over her arms like some ignorant bog woman just because her friend Mycah told her it would stop the itching. (AGOT, Sansa I)

Here we see connection of mud and healing qualities – which might be a nod to the earth magic.

I do think that Arya’s strong connection to mud has multiple purposes: It shows, that Arya, who looks like Ned, also has a very strong connection to her mother, and actually is far more similar to her in temper than she is to Ned. Others have made this observation before me: Arya looks like Ned, but is like Catelyn in temper, while Sansa looks like Catelyn, but has several traits of Ned. I do think that this further points towards the fact that Arya will meet Lady Stoneheart at one time in the book and will be present at the Red Wedding 2.0. (as she was in the show).

Mud repeatedly occurs to ‘ground’ Arya when she is on the run. It gives a hint about the people she can trust. When Yoren talks with Ned, and Arya sees him, the man from the Watch who will take her away from King’s Landing he wears mud-cacked boots (AGOT, Eddard VII).

Later when Arya travels with Yoren, it is Hot Pie, part of her ‘new’ family who is called ‘mud pie’:

Lommy and Tarber stripped naked and went wading, and Lommy scooped up handfuls of slimy mud and threw them at Hot Pie, shouting, “Mud Pie! Mud Pie!” (ACOK, Arya IV).

This is a clear connection to Catelyn baking mud pies with her sister.

In addition, Arya feels positively good with water and mud:

Despondent, she climbed off her horse and knelt by the lake. The water lapped softly around her legs. A few lantern bugs were coming out, their little lights blinking on and off. The green water was warm as tears, but there was no salt in it. It tasted of summer and mud and growing things. Arya plunged her face down into it to wash off the dust and dirt and sweat of the day. When she leaned back the trickles ran down the back of her neck and under her collar. They felt good. (ACOK, Arya IV)

And later in the same chapter, crawling in the mud saves her life:

Arya rolled headfirst into the tunnel and dropped five feet. She got dirt in her mouth but she didn’t care, the taste was fine, the taste was mud and water and worms and life. Under the earth the air was cool and dark. Above was nothing but blood and roaring red and choking smoke and the screams of dying horses. She moved her belt around so Needle would not be in her way, and began to crawl. A dozen feet down the tunnel she heard the sound, like the roar of some monstrous beast, and a cloud of hot smoke and black dust came billowing up behind her, smelling of hell. Arya held her breath and kissed the mud on the floor of the tunnel and cried. For whom, she could not say.  (ACOK, Arya IV)

Later when she has to walk barefoot she does not mind:

The mud was nice between her toes, and she liked to feel the earth underfoot when she walked. (ACOK, Arya V)

Arya is - at least it looks like that - directly identified with mud, although the woman might be talking about Lem here:

The painted sign above the door showed a picture of some old king on his knees. Inside was the common room, where a very tall ugly woman with a knobby chin stood with her hands on her hips, glaring. “Don’t just stand there, boy,” she snapped. “Or are you a girl? Either one, you’re blocking my door. Get in or get out. Lem, what did I tell you about my floor? You’re all mud.” (ASOS, Arya II)

I think it is interesting that Jaqen as one of the men who seemingly helps Arya has no connection to mud. The magic of the faceless men seems to draw Arya away from her family. It is no earth/water magic.

There is only one time, where Arya has a distinctively bad feeling about mud. It is a very ominous dream of Arya, which is a foreshadowing of the Red Wedding and her inability to help her family. It is also a back reference to Sansa and her inability to help her father (who was already beheaded by the time she walked through ‘ankle-deep mud’, forced by Joffrey to look at her father’s head).

She dreamt of home; not Riverrun, but Winterfell. It was not a good dream, though. She was alone outside the castle, up to her knees in mud. She could see the grey walls ahead of her, but when she tried to reach the gates every step seemed harder than the one before, and the castle faded before her, until it looked more like smoke than granite. (ASOS, Arya III)

Just like Sansa couldn’t help her father, Arya can’t help her mother and Robb.

This all cumulates in the almost reunion at the Red Wedding where mud occurs very frequently in Arya’s PoV.

“Come with me.” Sandor Clegane reached down a hand. “We have to get away from here, and now.” Stranger tossed his head impatiently, his nostrils flaring at the scent of blood. The song was done. There was only one solitary drum, its slow monotonous beats echoing across the river like the pounding of some monstrous heart. The black sky wept, the river grumbled, men cursed and died. Arya had mud in her teeth and her face was wet. Rain. It’s only rain. That’s all it is. “We’re here,” she shouted. Her voice sounded thin and scared, a little girl’s voice. “Robb’s just in the castle, and my mother. The gate’s even open.” There were no more Freys riding out. I came so far. “We have to go get my mother.” (ASOS, Arya IX)

The most heartbreaking connection of mud to Arya’s family and in particular her mother is still to come though: Nymeria drags Catelyn’s corpse from the mud of the river (remember the burial place of the Tullys) but she cannot help Catelyn, who is dead.

… and then she could smell her. The scent was faint beneath the other smells, beneath moss and mud and water, and the stench of rotting reeds and rotting men. She padded slowly through the soft ground to the river’s edge, lapped up a drink, the lifted her head to sniff. The sky was grey and thick with cloud, the river green and full of floating things. Dead men clogged the shallows, some still moving as the water pushed them, others washed up on the banks. ….

She splashed noisily through the shallows and threw herself into the deeper water, her legs churning. The current was strong but she was stronger. She swam, following her nose. The river smells were rich and wet, but those were not the smells that pulled her. She paddled after the sharp red whisper of cold blood, the sweet cloying stench of death. She chased them as she had often chased a red deer through the trees, and in the end she ran them down, and her jaw closed around a pale white arm. She shook it to make it move, but there was only death and blood in her mouth. By now she was tiring, and it was all she could do to pull the body back to shore. As she dragged it up the muddy bank, one of her little brothers came prowling, his tongue lolling from his mouth. She had to snarl to drive him off, or else he would have fed. Only then did she stop to shake the water from her fur. The white thing lay facedown in the mud, her dead flesh wrinkled and pale, cold blood trickling from her throat. Rise, she thought. Rise and eat and run with us. (ASOS, Arya XII)

I do think that the colour red probably is put here to make a connection to the red of the Tully mud, and of course the blood that was spilt when Catelyn was killed.

It is interesting, that as soon as Arya is in Braavos, the occurrence of mud decreases, because she disconnects with her family. It is also a strong hint, that the Faceless men will not be Arya’s family, that she’ll ultimately reject being part of them (like she did on the show). It is only in Arya’s dreams, that mud occurs:

It was the other dream she hated, the one where she had two feet instead of four. In that one she was always looking for her mother, stumbling through a wasted land of mud and blood and fire. It was always raining in that dream, and she could hear her mother screaming, but a monster with a dog’s head would not let her go save her. In that dream she was always weeping, like a frightened little girl. Cats never weep, she told herself, no more than wolves do. It’s just a stupid dream. (AFFC, Cat of the Canals)

Clearly, this dream is induced by Arya’s trauma.

So, mud, the combination of earth and water clearly occurs to ‘ground’ Arya, to give her a connection to her mother’s family, which will come into play again, once she returns to Westeros. But the Tully connection, earth/water magic connection is not the only thing that stands out about mud.

4) Mud and Blood

Another interesting find in connection with mud is that there are multiple times that mud and blood are connected. In a way, this occurs naturally, the gritty realism of the fighting in GRRM’s world is pictured by ‘dirty’ fights and therefore mud often occurs in fights, e.g at the tourney in King’s Landing (AGOT, Eddard VII), or Robert’s death (AGOT, Eddard XIII). Also, this fight of Brienne and Jaime might be put here:

Brienne lurched to her feet. She was all mud and blood below the waist, her clothing askew, her face red. She looks as if they caught us fucking instead of fighting. (ASOS, Jaime III)

As well as this fight from Asha’s PoV

When he fell, Hagen’s daughter stumbled to her knees, snatched up his sword, stabbed the second man, then rose again, smeared with blood and mud, her long red hair unbound, and plunged into the fight. (ADWD, The Wayward bride)

So, these are just two examples where the mud adds to the ‘dirtyness’ of fighting, there are many more.

5) Mud and slipping/falling

A very special case of mud and fighting is when a fight ends with someone lying in the mud. Over the course of ASOIAF several people come to lay in the mud, wounded, hurt or near to death, and I think this might be way to alert us to a connection of mud and death.

The very first time is in the prologue – which is also a foreshadowing of Jon’s death as @lady-in-a-song has shown:

The great sentinel was right there at the top of the ridge, where Will had known it would be, its lowest branches a bare foot off the ground. Will slid in underneath, flat on his belly in the snow and the mud, and looked down on the empty clearing below. (AGOT, Prologue)

When Ned and Jaime fight, Ned falls from his horse and lies in the mud:

Ned’s horse slipped under him and came crashing down in the mud. There was a moment of blinding pain and the taste of blood in his mouth. (AGOT, Eddard IX)

When he opened his eyes again, Lord Eddard Stark was alone with his dead. His horse moved closer, caught the rank scent of blood, and galloped away. Ned began to drag himself through the mud, gritting his teeth at the agony in his leg. It seemed to take years. (AGOT, Eddard IX)

Tyrion also has a muddy experience in his first battle:

Tyrion lurched to his feet, driving his head into the horse’s belly. The animal gave a hideous scream and reared. It tried to twist away from the agony, a shower of blood and viscera poured down over Tyrion’s face, and the horse fell like an avalanche. The next he knew, his visor was packed with mud and something was crushing his foot. He wriggled free, his throat so tight he could scarce talk. “… yield …” he managed to croak faintly. (AGOT, Tyrion VIII))

Several people land on their arses in the mud, which is not necessarily connected to dying. Arya does when she travels with the hound (ASOS, Arya XI), Podrick Payne falls in the mud, when Brienne catches him spying on her (AFFC, Brienne II) and Jaime kisses the muddy ground in his training exercise with Ser Ilyn (AFFC, Jaime V).

Yet, coming to fall in the mud, might be considered a bad omen, or at least a sign of sudden change. I think that mud and blood connected are not only there to convey a ‘dirty’ fight, but also to foreshadow bad things to come. It is no happenstance that Ned falls into the mud when he is confronted by Jaime Lannister in the streets of King’s Landing.

It is interesting that we see Ser Criston Cole, the commander of the King’s Guard, and in part a Jaime stand-in, actually killing a man in the mud:

Cole’s favorite weapon was the Morningstar, and the blows he rained done on Ser Laenor’s champion cracked his helm and left him senseless in the mud. Borne bloody from the field, Ser Joffrey died without recovering consciousness six days later. (F&B, Heirs of the dragon)

The scene with the most ominous foreshadowing is Jon: He is thrown into the mud, when he is attacked by Orell’s eagle. Jon’s fall and death and loss of an eye (on this compare @rose-of-red-lake) are foreshadowed several times, and Ned’s fall into the mud might be another hint to Jon’s falling, which we see here:

The next he knew, he was on his face with the taste of mud and blood in his mouth and Ygritte kneeling over him protectively, a bone dagger in her hand. He could still hear wings, though the eagle was not in sight. Half his world was black. “My eye,” he said in sudden panic, raising a hand to his face. …. “There’s your hellcrow!” Rattleshirt pointed at Jon. “Bleeding in the mud like a faithless dog!” The eagle came flapping down to land atop the broken giant’s skull that served him for his helm. “I’m here for him.” (ASOS, Jon II)

I would alert you to the fact that Duncan the Tall in the Hedge Knight also has a scene with mud and blood – and he is temporarily blinded by blood in his eye.

When his eyes opened he was on the ground again, sprawled on his back. The mud had all been knocked from his helm, but now one eye was closed by blood. Above was nothing but dark grey sky. (The Hedge Knight)

A variant of this mud and blood connection is, when Khal Drogo is dying. He does not lie in the mud, but the mud plasters on his wound get mixed with blood.

When they were alone, Ser Jorah drew his dagger. Deftly, with a delicacy surprising in such a big man, he began to scrape away the black leaves and dried blue mud from Drogo’s chest. The plaster had caked hard as the mud walls of the Lamb Men, and like those walls it cracked easily. Ser Jorah broke the dry mud with his knife, pried the chunks from the flesh, peeled off the leaves one by one. A foul, sweet smell rose from the wound, so thick it almost choked her. The leaves were crusted with blood and pus, Drogo’s breast black and glistening with corruption. (AGOT, Daenerys VIII)

I think it is extremely interesting that the mud, that was used to cover his wounds is of blue colour, a Tully colour maybe?

5) Mud and death

But this is not all there is to ‘mud’. We have seen sliding in the ‘mud’ is a real danger for anyone fighting, but mud can be deadly in other ways as well:

During their travels Brienne and Podrick chance upon dangerous mud:

“Stay off the mud, child,” counseled Septon Meribald. “The mud is not fond of strangers. If you walk in the wrong place, it will open up and swallow you.”

“It’s only mud,” insisted Podrick.

“Until it fills your mouth and starts creeping up your nose. Then it’s death.” He smiled to take the chill off his words. “Wipe off that mud and have a slice of orange, lad.” (AFFC, Brienne V)

And later:

“If you would sleep beneath a roof tonight, you must climb off your horses and cross the mud with me. The path of faith, we call it. Only the faithful may cross safely. The wicked are swallowed by the quicksands, or drowned when the tide comes rushing in. None of you are wicked, I hope? Even so, I would be careful where I set my feet. Walk only where I walk, and you shall reach the other side.” (AFFC, Brienne VI)

There is even mud in connection with quicksands in one of Sansa’s chapters, the only time apart from her walking towards the rampart as if through ankle-deep mud, where mud has an appearance in her chapters and is not connected to Arya:

Huge flowers bloomed in the mud and floated on pools of stagnant water, but if you were stupid enough to leave the causeway to pluck them, there were quicksands waiting to suck you down, and snakes watching from the trees, and lizard-lions floating half-submerged in the water, like black logs with eyes and teeth. (AGOT, Sansa I)

Ser Davos has a near death experience after the Battle of the Blackwater and the mud proves dangerous in this case as well.

Panic took hold of him. His hands flailed against the bottom of the river and sent up a cloud of mud that blinded him. His chest was growing tighter by the instant. He clawed at the water, kicking, pushing himself, turning, his lungs screaming for air, kicking, kicking, lost now in the river murk, kicking, kicking, kicking until he could kick no longer. When he opened his mouth to scream, the water came rushing in, tasting of salt, and Davos Seaworth knew that he was drowning. (ASOS Davos I)

The incident in F&B, where an archmaester dies of slipping in the mud, might be a hint as well:

He proved more robust than his predecessor, serving the realm until 12 AC, when he slipped in the mud, broke his hip, and died soon thereafter…. (F&B, Three heads had the dragon)

I mean this might be coincidence, but GRRM could have simply said: He took a fall?

So, what is it with dangerous mud? Is this a hint that Arya will become very deadly indeed?

There is yet another thing, but I’m not entirely sure what to make of it:

6) Mud and (horse)shit

Another interesting tidbit is this scene with Theon on Pyke

Theon knelt. He had a purpose here, and might need Aeron’s help to achieve it. A crown was worth a little mud and horseshit on his breeches, he supposed. (ACOK, Theon I)

 - a very strange wording and connection of mud and shit, but one that happens again, with Jon of all people:

Go on, I’ll see to your horse. If it’s warm and dry inside, don’t tell me, I wasn’t asked in.“ He flicked a glob of wet mud out from under a horseshoe. "Does this mud look like shit to you? Could it be that this whole hill is made of Craster’s shit?” (ACOK, Jon III).

I would like to link this to the following from Catelyn’s chapters:

“The distance between a lord and a grace is a small one, my lady,” Catelyn said. “Lord Renly wears a crown, as does my son. If you wish, we may stand here in the mud and debate what honors and titles are rightly due to each, but it strikes me that we have more pressing matters to consider.” (ACOK, Catelyn II)

Is this a hint to the debate to come when the lords will discuss Jon’s claim to the crown?

So mud might be even involved with the making of a king? This is admittedly very tinfoily….

7) Mud as a part of nature

Another very prominent occurrence of mud is the connection of mud with Prince Quentyn, the ‘wrong suitor’, the frog prince who was not saved by princess Dany but failed in his bride quest. This is what Barristan has to say about Quentyn being mud :

She wants fire, and Dorne sent her mud.

You could make a poultice out of mud to cool a fever. You could plant seeds in mud and grow a crop to feed your children. Mud would nourish you, where fire would only consume you, but fools and children and young girls would choose fire every time. (ADWD, the discarded knight)

Here mud has very positive connotations, something that connects mud to healing and fertility.

So, mud is much more dangerous than people allow for, but is also good. It’s not just water and earth, there is more to it and maybe even the connection of mud and death might have a positive aspect:

Firewights of Rh’llor and the icewights of the Others are unnatural, and if it is indeed Arya’s fate to come to a deeper understanding of mercy, justice and revenge, then the final death of Lady Stoneheart – which she probably will witness – brings the natural order back.

I suggest that mud might point not only to Tullys, to danger and to death, but that it might also point towards a fall and a sudden change.

Arya is the ‘wild card’. Where her allegiance lies, will probably be crucial, and the despised mud might become dangerous up to a point where the mud can suffocate and kill someone.

7) Mud and danger

Finally, I would alert you to some ominous foreshadowing of mud and water besides the connection to Khal Drogo’s death I have discussed already.

Mud features heavily in the tragic story of Da€nerys, Drogo and Mirri Maaz Duur.

“I meant no wrong, fierce riders.” The woman spoke Dothraki well. The robes she wore had once been the lightest and finest of woolens, rich with embroidery, but now they were mud-caked and bloody and ripped. She clutched the torn cloth of her bodice to her heavy breasts. “I have some small skill in the healing arts.” (AGOT, Daenerys VII)

Mirri is a healer, and it is interesting that her and her magic (we only see her practicing blood magic, but it stands to reason that her normal way of magic would be ‘earth-bound’).

Khal Drogo waved him away. “I need no man’s help,” he said, in a voice proud and hard. He stood, unaided, towering over them all. A fresh wave of blood ran down his breast, from where Ogo’s arakh had cut off his nipple. Dany moved quickly to his side. “I am no man,” she whispered, “so you may lean on me.” Drogo put a huge hand on her shoulder. She took some of his weight as they walked toward the great mud temple. The three bloodriders followed. Dany commanded Ser Jorah and the warriors of her khas to guard the entrance and make certain no one set the building afire while they were still inside. (AGOT, Daenerys VII)

I would alert you to the fact, that Khal Drogo burns the mud temple of the Lamb people. So, MMD connected to mud via her religion – which is a religion that seems to be heavily influenced by earth and nature worship  – is an antagonist of Da€nerys.

Considering that Da€nerys lives in a hot climate, the rare occurrence of mud may alert us to important crossroads of her arc.

The procession waited on the grassy shore as Dany stripped and let her soiled clothing fall to the ground. Naked, she stepped gingerly into the water. Irri said the lake had no bottom, but Dany felt soft mud squishing between her toes as she pushed through the tall reeds. The moon floated on the still black waters, shattering and re-forming as her ripples washed over it. Goose pimples rose on her pale skin as the coldness crept up her thighs and kissed her lower lips. The stallion’s blood had dried on her hands and around her mouth. Dany cupped her fingers and lifted the sacred waters over her head, cleansing herself and the child inside her while the khal and the others looked on. She heard the old women of the dosh khaleen muttering to each other as they watched, and wondered what they were saying. (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

This happens after Da€nerys ate the horse heart and awaits the dosh khaleen’s prophecy on the future of her child, the “stallion who mounts the world”. This is when Viserys dies and she sets herself on the path towards winning the Iron Throne for herself.

In her last chapter in ADWD (Da€nerys X) there is a recollection of the time she was pregnant with Rhaego:

It was quiet on her sea. When the wind blew the grass would sigh as the stalks brushed against each other, whispering in a tongue that only gods could understand. Now and again the little stream would gurgle where it flowed around a stone. Mud squished between her toes. Insects buzzed around her, lazy dragonflies and glistening green wasps and stinging midges almost too small to see. She swatted at them absently when they landed on her arms.

Her last chapter in ADWD is also important, because she really embraces her house words ‘fire and blood’, the last step in her transition from a frightened child to a ruthless conqueror. This is also the chapter, where we see her possibly having a miscarriage:

Her belly was empty, her feet sore and blistered, and it seemed to her that the cramping had grown worse. Her guts were full of writhing snakes biting at her bowels. She scooped up a handful of mud and water in trembling hands. By midday the water would be tepid, but in the chill of dawn it was almost cool and helped her keep her eyes open. As she splashed her face, she saw fresh blood on her thighs. The ragged hem of her undertunic was stained with it. The sight of so much red frightened her. Moon blood, it’s only my moon blood, but she did not remember ever having such a heavy flow. Could it be the water? If it was the water, she was doomed. She had to drink or die of thirst. (ADWD Daenerys X)

Very tentatively I would suggest that ‘mud’ and/ or water does not bode well for Da€nerys. If it was the water, she was doomed. Who has the strongest connection to the Riverlands? Who is a waterdancer? Arya, the wild card, will be threat to Da€nerys I’m sure of it.

To sum up:

Mud as a combination of earth and water has a connection to the CotF and might be usable to balance the dangerous opposites of fire and ice.

Mud is a tell-tale Tully word. The red mud of the river is a sign for Tully, and it shows clearly that appearances put aside, Arya is the child that is most closely connected to the Tully and the Riverlands and will probably witness the Red Wedding 2.0. and the final death of the unnaturally resurrected Lady Stoneheart. Arya possibly will choose mud over fire.

Mud and blood are used repeatedly – and many more times when I put down here as examples – to picture the dirtiness of fighting. Mud also has healing qualities, but can be dangerous as well (as every magic). We see this rarely, but nevertheless in every book and in several PoVs.

There is a connection between mud and death. Slipping in the mud can mean a sudden change to a fight and deadly danger. I would alert you to the fact that the healing qualities of mud only go awry when the healing women of the Dothraki fail to heal Khal Drogo.

Looking at Da€nerys’ arc I would say that mud does not bode well for her. Mud as a reminder of a more grounded life occurs at several crossroads in her arc, shortly before Viserys’ death, with MMD, with the rejection of Quentyn’s offer of marriage and the decision for her house words in her last chapter in ADWD. I think it points towards the fact that the very personification of ‘mud’, Arya Stark will cause a turn in Da€nerys’ story. I do think it is a further hint that Arya will be the death of Da€nerys.
trail.content_abstract:
In ASOIAF we have two very obvious sources of magic: The Ice of the WW north of the Wall and the fire that is present in the dragons and Rh’llors magic. Both magics seem to be very strong – both the WW and the servants of Rh’llor can resurrect the dead – producing ice wights or fire wights, respectively.

It has puzzled me for some time, that as regards to the traditional four elements “earth, fire, air and water”, the two opposites “ice and fire” do not exactly match. Fire obviously melts ice, but then ice becomes water that will extinguish the fire in turn. So, why ice and not water as an opposite to fire?

I put this under the cut because it became huge…
